And for thus regarding a sinner as I am,
I eftsoons thank thee oh lord God of Abraham,
Thy mercy and wisdom shall I sing evermore:
And magnify thy name, for gods there is no more.
But I will to my husband Isaac, and see,
That for this matter he take no grief at me.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.l: Nay, now at last we have well sped I warrant you:
Ragau bringeth venison at his back.good luck is not evermore against Esau.
He coursed and coursed again with his dogs here:
But they could at no time take either hare or deer.
At last he killed this with his bow as God would.
And to say that it is fat venison be bold.
But dressed it must be at once in all the haste,
That old father Isaac may have his repast.
Then without delay Esau shall blessed be,
Than faith cock on hoop, all is ours, then who but he?
But I must in that it may be dressed in time likely,
And I trow ye shall see it made ready quickly.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.l: Nay now old master Isaac (I warrant you)
Hath blessed Jacob in the place of Esau.
At home here with us it is judged no small change
But a case wonderful, and also very strange.
The younger brother is made elder, and again,
The elder must now serve the younger as his swain.
And from henceforth we must all make courtesy and bow,
Unto master Jacob, and not to Esau now:
And Esau himself must under Jacob been,
At his commandment even as well as we.
But I care not I warrant you: for our household
Love Jacob better than Esau twenty fold.
None loveth Esau but for his father's sake:
But all good folks are glad Jacob's part to take.
And now by Esau no man will set a pin,
But yonder he cometh now, I will get me in.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: I trow I have now won my spurs for ever,
For once better venison killed I never.
And though it were somewhat longer I could it take,
Yet the goodness thereof doth some recompense make.
My father Isaac shall thereof have such meat,
As in all his life he hath not the better eat.
Whereupon I doubt not, after tender kissing,
To be straight endowed with his godly blessing.
As his full and true heir in his place to succeed,
And t'enjoy the promise that God made to his seed,
And when I am once in my place of succession,
And have all manner things in full possession:
I shall wring all louts and make them stoop (I trow)
I shall make the slave's couch as low as dog to bow.
I shall ruffle among them of another sort,
Than Isaac hath done, and with another port.
But now will I go see what hast within they make
That part of my hunting my old father may take.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Mido, come Mido, where art thou little Mido?

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: Here ready master Isaac, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Come lead me to mine old place, that I may sit down

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: That can I as well as any boy in this town.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: O lord my God, how deep and unsearchable
Are all thy judgements, and how immutable?
Of thy justice, whom it pleaseth thee, thou dost reject,
Of thy mercy, whom pleaseth thee, thou dost elect.
In my two sons oh lord, thou hast wrought thy will,
And as thy pleasure hath wrought, so shall it stand still.
Since thou hast set Jacob in Esau his place:
I commit him to the governance of thy grace.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Now where is Isaac that he may come and eat?
Lo where he is sitting abroad upon his seat.
Dear father Isaac, the lord thy god thee save.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Who art thou my son? And what thing wouldst thou have?

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: I am your eldest son Esau by my name,
New come home from hunting, where I had jolly game,
I have made meat thereof for your own appetite,
Meat for your own tooth, wherein ye will much delight.
Come eat your part, dear father, that when ye have done,
Your soul may bless me as your heir and eldest son.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Ah Esau, Esau, thou comest too late,
Another to thy blessing was predestinate,
And clean gone it is from thee Esau.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Alas,
Then am I the unhappiest that ever was,
I would the savage beasts had my body torn.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: The blessing that thou shouldst have had, another hath

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Alas, what wretched villain hath done me such scathe?

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Thy brother Jacob came to me by subtlety,
and brought me venison, and so prevented thee.
I eat with him ere thou camest, and with my good will,
Blessed him I have, and blessed he shall be still.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Ah Jacob, Jacob, well may he be called so:
For he hath undermined me times two.
For first mine heritage he took away me fro,
And see, now hath he away my blessing also.
Ah father, father, though Jacob hath done this thing:
Yet let me Esau also have thy blessing.
Shall all my good huntings for thee be in vain?

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: That is done and passed, can not be called again.
Mine act must now stand in force of necessity.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: And hast thou never a blessing then left for me?

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Behold, I have made thy brother Jacob thy lord.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: A most poignant sword unto my heart is that word.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: All his mother's children his servants have I made.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: That word is to me sharper than a razor's blade.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: I have also established him with wine and corn.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Woe be the day and hour that ever I was born.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: What am I able to do for thee my son?

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Ah Jacob, Jacob, that thou hast me thus undone.
O unhappy hap: o misfortune, well away,
That ever I should live to see this woeful day.
But hast thou one blessing and no more my father?
Let me also have some blessing good sweet father.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Well, nature pricketh me some remorse on thee to have.
Behold, thy dwelling place the earth's fatness shall have.
And the dew of heaven which down from above shall fall:
And with dint of sword thy living get thou shall.
And to thy brother Jacob thou shalt be servant.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: O, to my younger brother must I be servant?
O, that ever a man should be so oppressed.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Thine own fault it is that thou art dispossessed.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Father, change that piece of thy sentence and judgement.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Things done can not be undone, therefore be content,
Let me be in quiet, and trouble me no more.
Come Mido, in god's name lead me in at the door.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: O would not this chafe a man, and fret his guts out?
To live as an underling under such a lout?
Ah hypocrite, ah hedge-creeper, ah sembling wretch:
I will be even with thee for this subtle fetch.
O God of Abraham, what reason is herein,
That to slay ones enemy it should be made sin?
Were not one as good his part of heaven forgo,
As not to be revenged on his deadly foe?
God was angry with Cain for killing Abel:
Else might I kill Jacob marvellously well.
I may fortune one day him to dispatch and rid:
The lord will not see all things, some thing may be hid.
But as for these misers within my father's tent,
Which to the supplanting of me put their consent,
Not one, but I shall coil them till they stink for pain,
And then for their stinking, coil them of fresh again.
I will take no days, but while the matter is hot,
Not one of them shall scape but they shall to the pot.

div.head: Actus quinti, scaena quinta.
div.l: Where are we now become? marry sir here is array,
With Esau my master this is a black day.
I told you, Esau one day would shite a rag,
Have not we well hunted, of blessing to come lag?
Nay I thought ever it would come to such a pass,
Since he sold his heritage like a very ass.
But in faith some of them I dare jeopard a groat,
If he may reach them, will have on the petticoat.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Come out whores and thieves, come out, come out I say.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.p: I told you, did I not? that there would be a fray.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Come out little whoreson ape, come out of thy den.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: Take my life for a penny, whether shall I run?

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Come out thou little fiend, come out thou skittish Gill.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Out alas, alas, Esau will us all kill.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: And come out thou mother Mab, out old rotten witch,
As white as midnight's arsehole, or virgin pitch.
Where be ye? come together in a cluster.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.p: In faith and these thrée will make a noble muster.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Ere ye escape my fingers, ye shall all be taught.
For these be they which have all this against me wrought.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.l: I wrought not a stroke this day but led Isaac.
If I wrought one stroke today, lay me on the jack.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Hence then, get thee in, and do against me no more.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: I care as much for you now, as I did before.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: What sayest thou little thief? if I may thee catch,

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: Ye shall run apace then I ween, so God me snatch.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.l: Now to go Mido, or thou art caught in a trip,

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Nay for his sake, Abra, ye shall drink of the whip.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.l: Nay for God's love good sweet master Esau,
Hurt not me for Mido: speak for me Ragau.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.p: Sir spare little Abra, she hath done none evil.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: A little fiend it is, and will be a right devil,
And she is one of them that love not me a deal.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: If ye let me go, I will love you very well.

sp.speaker: Esau·
sp.p: And never any more ado against me make?

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Ragau shall be surety.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.p: Sir I undertake.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Then hence out of my sight at once, and get thee in.

sp.speaker: Abra.
sp.p: Adieu, I set not a straw by you nor a pin.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: What sayest thou thou Ti●? once ye shall have a rap.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.l: The best end of suretyship is to get a clap,

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Now come on thou old hag, what shall I say to thee?

sp.speaker: Deborra.
sp.p: Say what ye lust, so ye do not touch me.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Yes, and make powder of thee, for I dare say, thou,
Hast been the cause of all this feast to Esau.

sp.speaker: Deborra.
sp.p: No it was Jacob's feast that I did help to dress.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Nay I thought such a witch would do such business.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: But by my truth if I should die incontinent,
I knew not of the purpose wherefore it was meant.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: But wilt thou tell me truth if I do forgive thee?

sp.speaker: Deborra.
sp.p: Yea if I can master Esau, believe me.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Is it true that when I and my brother were first born,
And I by god's ordinance came forth him before,
Jacob came forthwith, holding me fast by the he'll?

sp.speaker: Deborra.
sp.p: It is true, I was there, and saw it very well.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Is it true? well Jacob I pray God I be dead,
But for my heels' sake, I will have thee by the head.
What devil was in me, that I had not the grace
With kicking back my he'll to mar his mopish face?
But my father Isaac will not long live now,
If he were gone, Jacob I would soon meet with you.
For my soul hateth Jacob even to the death,
And I will ne'er but hate him while I shall have breath.
I may well dissemble until I see a day:
But trust me Jacob, I will pay thee when I may.
This he speaketh to Deborra.but if ever I hear that thou speak word of this,
I shall cut out thy tongue, I will not miss.
But come on Ragau with me, so mote I thrive,
I will get a good sword, for thereby must I live.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.p: Live quod you? we are like to live God knoweth how.

sp.speaker: Esau·
sp.p: What ye saucy merchant, are ye a prater now?

sp.speaker: Deborra.
sp.l: I am glad that Esau is now gone certes.
For an evil disposed man he is doubtless.
Yet am I no gladder of his departure hence,
Than I am that Rebecca is come in presence.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Deborah, what dost thou tarrying here so long?
I came full ill afeard lest some thing had been wrong
For Mido and Abra told me of Esau.

sp.speaker: Deborra.
sp.l: In deed here he was, and departed hence but now:
And one thing I tell you dame, let Jacob beware,
For Esau to mischief Jacob doth prepare,

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Call Jacob hither, that I may show him my mind.
Send him hither quickly, and tarry ye behind.
That he give place awhile, it is expedient,
And how he may be sure, I will the way invent.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Mother Rebecca, did ye send for me hither?

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Yea and the cause is this, thou must go somewhither,
To hide thee from thy brother Esau a space.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: In deed to men's malice we must sometime give place.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: He lieth in await, to slay thee if he can.
Thou shalt therefore by my rede flee hence to Haran,
And lie with my brother Laban a man aged,
Till Esau's wrath be somewhat assuaged.
When all things are forgotten, and his fury past,
I shall send for thee again in all goodly haste.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Yea, but how will my father herewith be content?

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Thou shalt see me win him thereto incontinent.
And here he cometh happily, Jacob hear me,
Make a sign to Mido, that he do not name thee,
Then get thee in privily till I do thee call.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: As ye command me mother Rebecca, I shall.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Where be ye good wife?

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: My dame Rebecca is here.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: I am glad sweet husband that I see you appear,

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: For I have a word or two unto you to say.
Whatsoever it be, tell it me I you pray.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Sir ye know, that now our life days are but short
and we had never so great need of comfort,
Now Esau his wives being Hethites both,
Ye know to please us are much unwilling and loath.
That if Jacob eke would take any Hittite to wife,
Small joy should we both have or comfort of our life.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Wife ye speak this well, and I will provide therefore,
Call Jacob quickly, that he appear me before.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: I can run apace for him if ye bid me go.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: Go hie thee at once then like a good son Mido.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: O lord save thou my son from miscarrying.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.l: Come master Jacob, ye must make no tarrying,
For I it is that shall be shent if you be slack,
Here is your son Jacob now master Isaac.

sp.speaker: Isaac
sp.l: Son Jacob, make thee ready as fast thou can,
And in all haste possible get thee unto Laban.
He is thine own uncle, and a right godly man,
Marry of his daughters, and not of Canan.
In Mesopotamia shalt thou lead thy life.
The lord prosper thee there, without debate or strife.
And the god of Abraham prosper thee in peace,
He multiply thy seed, and make it to increase,
Now kiss me dear son Jacob, and so go thy way.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: Kiss me also sweet son, and hence without delay.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.l: Now most tender parents, as well with heart and word,
I bid you well to fare, and leave you to the lord.

sp.speaker: Mido.
sp.p: Nay master Jacob, let me have an hand also.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.p: Even with all my heart farewell little Mido.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Now will I depart hence into the tent again.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: As pleaseth God and you, but I will here remain.

div.head: Actus quinti, scaena decima.
div.l: And is he gone in deed to mine uncle Laban,
In Mesopotamia at the town of Haran?
And is Jacob gone to the house of Bethuel?
The whirlwind with him, and flinging fiend of hell.
But I shall meet with him yet one day well enough.
And who is this? my mother, whom I see here now?

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.p: She stood here all this while sir, did ye not her see?

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Didst thou see her stand here, and wouldst not warn me?

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Son Esau, afore God thou art much to blame,
And to do as I hear of thee, is a foul shame.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: Mother what is it ye heard of me of late?

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: That thou dost thy brother Jacob deadly hate.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Hate Jacob? I hate him and will do till I die.
For he hath done me both great wrong and villainy.
And that shall he well know if the lord give me life.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: Fie upon thee to speak so like a lewd caitiff.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.l: My master Esau is of nature much hot,
But he will be better than he saith, fear not.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: My birthright to sell did he not make me consent?

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: But the same to do were not thyself content?
There is no man to blame for it but thine own self.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Yea mother, see that ye hold with that mopish elf.
It is your dainty darling, your princock, your golpol,
He can never be praised enough of your soul,
He must ever be extolled above the moon,
It is never amiss that he hath said or done.
I would he were rocked or dandled in your lap:
Or I would with this falchion I might give him pap.
I marvel why ye should so love him, and me not?
Ye groaned as well for the one as tother I wot.
But Jacob must be advanced in any wise:
But I shall one day handle him of the new guise.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Both on thy father's blessing and mine I charge thee,
That thy soul intend never such iniquity,
Beware by the example of Cain I thee rede,
That thou bring not the lords curse upon thy head.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: And what should I take all this wrong at Jacob's hand?

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Forgive, and the lord shall prosper thee on the land.
My son Esau hear me, I am thy mother:
For my sake let pass this grudge against thy brother.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.l: Sir, your mother's request is but reasonable,
Which for you to grant shall be much commendable.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Mother, though it be a great thing that ye require:
Yet must all malice pass at your desire.
And for your cause mother, this mine anger shall slake.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: I thank thee my son, that thou dost it for my sake

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: For your sake with Jacob I will be at accord.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: And shall I call thy father to be as record?

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.p: As pleaseth you mother, I can be well content.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Then will I go call him hither incontinent.
And where he doth already love thee very well,
This will make him to love thee better a great deal.

sp.speaker: Ragau.
sp.l: Truly sir, this is of you a right gentle part:
At least if it come from the bottom of your heart.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: It must now be thus, but when I shall Jacob find,
I shall then do, as God shall put into my mind.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: He hath at my word remitted all his quarrel.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Forsooth I love him the better a great deal.
And if he be here, I would commend his doing.
All pressed here father to tarry on your coming.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.p: Son Esau, thou haste thyself well acquitted.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: That all quarrel to Jacob thou haste remitted.
It was the lord's pleasure that it should thus be,
Against whose ordinance to stand is not for thee:
But now to the intent it may please the lord,
To knit your hearts one day in a perfect concord,
We shall first in a song give laud unto his name,
And than with all gladness, within confirm the same.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.p: As ye think best dear husband I agree thereto.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Me ye may command to what ye will have me to do:
And so may ye do also Ragau my man.

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: I see none, but praise we the lord the hest we can.
Call forth all our household that with one accord,
we may all with one voice sing unto the lord. Ragau calleth all to sing.
sp.stage: This song must be song after the prayer.

lg.l: O lord the god of our father Abraham,
How deep and unsearchable are thy judgements ▪
Thy almightiful hand did create and frame,
Both heaven and earth and all the elements.
Man of the earth thou haste formed and create,
Some do thee worship, and some stray awry,
Whom pleaseth thee, thou dost choose or reprobate,
And no flesh can ask thee wherefore or why?
Of thine own will thou didst Abraham elect,
Promising him seed as stars of the sky,
And them as thy chosen people to protect,
That they might thy mercies praise and magnify.
Perform thou oh lord, thine eternal decree,
To me and my seed the sons of Abraham,
And whom thou haste chosen thine own people to be,
Guide and defend to the glory of thy name. Finis.

sp.stage: Then entereth the poet, and the rest stand still, till he have done.
sp.l: When Adam for breaking God's commandmentThe poet entereth.
Had sentence of death, and all his posterity:
Yet the lord our god who is omnipotent,
Had in his own self by his eternal decree,
Appointed to restore man, and to make him free,
He purposed to save mankind by his mercy,
Whom he once had created unto his glory.
Yet not all flesh did he then predestinate,
But only the adopted children of promise:
For he foreknew that many would degenerate,
And wilfully give cause to be put from that bliss:
So on god's behalf no manner default there is,
but where he chooseth, he showeth his great mercy:
And where he refuseth, he doth none injury,
But thus far surmounteth man's intellection,
To attain or conceive, and much more to discuss:
All must be referred to God's election,
And to his secret judgement, it is meet for us,
With Paul the apostle to confess and say thus:
O the deepness of the riches of God's wisdom,
How unsearchable are his ways to man's reason?
Our part therefore is first to believe God's word,
Not doubting but that he will his elected save:
Then to put full trust in the goodness of the lord,
That we be of the number which shall mercy have:
Thirdly so to live as we may his promise crave.
Thus if we do, we shall Abraham's children be:
And come with Jacob to endless felicity.

div.stage: All the rest of the actors answer amen

sp.speaker: Isaac.
sp.l: Now unto God let us pray for all the whole clergy,
To give them grace to avaunt god's honour and glory.

sp.speaker: Rebecca.
sp.l: Then for the Queen's majesty let us pray,
Unto God to keep her in health and wealth night and day,
And that of his mere mercy and great benignity,
He will defend and maintain her estate and dignity,
That she being grieved with any outward hostility,
May against her enemies, alway have victory.

sp.speaker: Jacob.
sp.l: God save the Queen's counsellors most noble and true,
And with all godliness their noble hearts endue.

sp.speaker: Esau.
sp.l: Lord save the nobility and preserve them all:
And prosper the Queen's subjects universal.

div.trailer: Thus endeth this comedy or interlude of Jacob and Esau.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
